member.name: T:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.Adornments.IViewElementFactory
member.summary: Converts from an object to its equivalent platform specific UI element.

remarks.para: This type allows the same intermediate type to be rendered on different platforms through the use of platform specific exports that live in that platform's UI layer.
You must specify the type converted from and the type converted to using .
You can supersede an existing converting for the same (to, from) pair via MEF s.

example.code: [Export(typeof(IViewElementFactory))] [Name("My object converter")] [TypeConversion(from: typeof(object), to: typeof(UIElement))] [Order(Before = "Default object converter")]

member.summary: Converts into an equivalent object of type .
member.exception: Thrown if the conversion is unknown or unsupported.
member.typeparam: The base type of the view element on the specific platform.
member.param: The view that owns the control that will host this view element.
The object to convert to a view element.
member.returns: A new object of type .

member.name: T:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.Adornments.IViewElementFactoryService
member.summary: A service for converting from data objects to their platform specific UI representation.
member.remarks:
This is a MEF service that can be obtained via the in a MEF exported class.
The editor supports s, , s, and on all platforms. Text and image elements are converted to colorized text and images respectively and other objects are displayed as the returned by unless an extender exports a for that type.
On Windows only, , , and UIElement are also directly supported.

member.param: The textView that owns the control that will host this view element.
The object to convert to a view element.
member.returns: A new object of type or null if the conversion is unknown.

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.Adornments.ToolTipParameters.Default
member.summary: Default options for a mouse tracking tooltip.

members.member:
Creates a new instance of .
If true, dismisses the tooltip when the mouse leaves the applicable span.
If true, and if the tooltip is mouse tracking, does not dismiss when the buffer changes.
A callback function that determines wehther or not to keep open the tooltip in mouse tracking sessions, despite the mouse being outside the tooltip.
If true, and if the tooltip is span tracking, does not dismiss when the caret position changes.
/// If true, and the tooltip is span tracking, dismisses the tooltip if it's scrolled off the screen or focus changes. If false, hides the tooltip in these scenarios, but shows it again when the span is back on the screen.

member.name: T:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.Editor.Commanding.Commands.RemoveLastSecondaryCaretCommandArgs
member.summary: This command refers to the gesture used to remove a secondary caret from a text view. The the caret to remove is identified as the last caret in a circular loop, starting at the primary caret. Effectively, that means either the caret directly above the primary caret, or the last one in the view. This command is not available if there is only one caret.

member.summary: This command refers to the gesture to change the primary caret to the next caret in the document, and make that visible to the user.

member.name: T:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.Editor.Commanding.Commands.RotatePrimaryCaretPreviousCommandArgs
member.summary: This command refers to the gesture to make the primary caret the next one up in the document, and make it visible to the user.

member.name: T:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.Editor.Commanding.ICommandingTextBufferResolver
member.summary: Given a text view and a command type, resolves a list of text buffers on which a command should be executed. Default implementation of this service returns a list of buffers in the text view which can be mapped to the caret position. Other implementations might take into acount text selection in addition to the caret position, for example when executing Format Document command in a projection scenario.

summary.para: Defines the mapping between character positions and scrollmap coordinates. This is not the same as the coordinate system in which the scrollbar is rendered.

remarks.para: Valid text positions range are [0...TextView.TextSnapshot.Length].
Corresponding scrollmap coordinates are [0.0 ... CoordinateOfBufferEnd].
Not every buffer position will have a distinct scrollmap coordinate. For example, every character on the same line of text will, generally, have the same scrollmap coordinate.
Different scrollmap coordinates may map to the same buffer position. For example, scrollmap coordinates in the range [0.0, 1.0) will, generally, map to the first character of the buffer.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.Editor.IScrollMap.GetCoordinateAtBufferPosition(Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.SnapshotPoint)
member.summary: Gets the scrollmap coordinates of a buffer position.
member.param: The buffer position.
member.returns: The scrollmap coordinate, which will be between 0.0 and CoordinateOfBufferEnd inclusive.

member.name: P:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.Editor.IScrollMap.AreElisionsExpanded
member.summary: Does the coordinate system used by this scroll map act as if all elisions are expanded?

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.Editor.IScrollMap.GetBufferPositionAtCoordinate(System.Double)
member.summary: Gets the buffer position that corresponds to a scrollmap coordinate.
member.param: The scrollmap coordinate.
member.returns: The corresponding buffer position.
member.exception: is NaN.
member.remarks: Different buffer positions can have the same scroll map coordinates. This method is guaranteed only to be consistent: it will return the same position for the same coordinate. The exact character returned will depend on the implementation of the scroll map. It will generally be the first character on the line.

member.remarks: This is equivalent to the scrollbar thumb size. The total height of the scroll map, in scrollmap coordinates, is CoordinateOfBufferEnd + ThumbSize.

summary.para: Represents the caret associated with an .

remarks.para: Most properties and parameters that are doubles correspond to coordinates or distances in the text rendering coordinate system. In this coordinate system, x = 0.0 corresponds to the left edge of the drawing surface onto which text is rendered (x = view.ViewportLeft corresponds to the left edge of the viewport), and y = view.ViewportTop corresponds to the top edge of the viewport. The x-coordinate increases from left to right, and the y-coordinate increases from top to bottom.

The horizontal and vertical axes of the view behave differently. When the text in the view is formatted, only the visible lines are formatted. As a result, a viewport cannot be scrolled horizontally and vertically in the same way.
A viewport is scrolled horizontally by changing the left coordinate of the viewport so that it moves with respect to the drawing surface.
A view can be scrolled vertically only by performing a new layout.

Doing a layout in the view may cause the ViewportTop property of the view to change. For example, scrolling down one line will not translate any of the visible lines. Instead it will simply change the view's ViewportTop property (causing the lines to move on the screen even though their y-coordinates have not changed).

Distances in the text rendering coordinate system correspond to logical pixels. If the text rendering surface is displayed without any scaling transform, then 1 unit in the text rendering coordinate system corresponds to one pixel on the display.

member.name: P:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.Editor.ITextCaret.OverwriteMode
member.summary: Determines whether the caret is in overwrite mode.

remarks.para: When the caret is in overwrite mode, typed characters replace the character under the caret, and a block is drawn instead of a vertical line.

This is distinct from the IEditorOptions overwrite mode, since the caret can switch modes based on its position in the view. The caret is not in OverwriteMode when it is positioned at the end of the line in a view, or when there is a non-empty selection, even if IEditorOptions.OverwriteMode is true.

member.name: P:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.Editor.ITextCaret.InVirtualSpace
member.summary: Determines whether the caret lies in virtual space. A virtual space is one that is after the physical end of a line.

remarks.para: This is distinct from the UseVirtualSpace, since virtual space can be enabled even if the caret does not lie in virtual space.

member.name: T:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.Editor.ITextView
member.summary: Represents a view of text in an . It is the base class for a platform-specific interface that has methods to allow the formatted text to be rendered.

remarks.para: A text view is a platform-independent representation of a contiguous block of formatted and adorned text, accessible through the property. It also instantiates an instance of an IEditorOperations component part so that it can execute various commands.
The text is formatted based on the classifiers attached to the underlying .

Most properties and parameters that are doubles correspond to coordinates or distances in the text rendering coordinate system. In this coordinate system, x = 0.0 corresponds to the left edge of the drawing surface onto which text is rendered (x = view.ViewportLeft corresponds to the left edge of the viewport), and y = view.ViewportTop corresponds to the top edge of the viewport. The x-coordinate increases from left to right, and the y-coordinate increases from top to bottom.

The horizontal and vertical axes of the view behave differently. When the text in the view is formatted, only the visible lines are formatted. As a result, a viewport cannot be scrolled horizontally and vertically in the same way.
A viewport is scrolled horizontally by changing the left coordinate of the viewport so that it moves with respect to the drawing surface.
A view can be scrolled vertically only by performing a new layout.

Doing a layout in the view may cause the ViewportTop property of the view to change. For example, scrolling down one line will not translate any of the visible lines. Instead it will simply change the view's ViewportTop property (causing the lines to move on the screen even though their y-coordinates have not changed).

Distances in the text rendering coordinate system correspond to logical pixels. If the text rendering surface is displayed without any scaling transform, then 1 unit in the text rendering coordinate system corresponds to one pixel on the display.

Otherwise, it is the distance from the bottom of the to the bottom on the view. Negative values are allowed, which might cause the line to be displayed outside the viewport. This method can become quite expensive if is large. You should avoid making greater than the height of the view.
Specifies whether the line offset is relative to the top or bottom of the view.
member.returns: The vertical distance (from the top or bottom of the view) at which the containing the specified position is to be displayed.

The returned value will generally be equal to , except in cases where the view was repositioned to prevent a gap from appearing at the top or bottom of the view.
Calling this method will cause the view to dispose of its current .

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.Editor.ITextView.QueueSpaceReservationStackRefresh
member.summary: Requests a refresh of the space reservation stack.
member.remarks: Refreshing the space reservation stack involves asking each of the space reservation managers/agents to reposition themselves. This method will be called mostly by space reservation agents that wish to reposition their content. The space reservation stack is refreshed asynchronously. Calling QueueSpaceReservationStackRefresh will perform a refresh of the space reservation stack, but the effects will not be visible immediately on return of the call.

member.name: P:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.Editor.ITextView.TextViewLines
member.summary: Gets a read-only list of the objects rendered in this view.
member.remarks:
This list will be dense. That is, all characters between the first character of the first through the last character of the last will be represented in one of the objects, except when the layout of the objects is in progress.
objects are disjoint. That is, a given character is part of only one .
The objects are sorted by the index of their first character.
Some of the objects may not be visible, and all objects will be disposed of when the view recomputes its layout.
This property will be null during the view's initialization.
member.exception: View is in the process of being laid out.

This list will be dense. That is, all characters between the first character of the first through the last character of the last will be represented in one of the objects, except when the layout of the objects is in progress.
objects are disjoint. That is, a given character is part of only one .
The objects are sorted by the index of their first character.
Some of the objects may not be visible, and all objects will be disposed of when the view recomputes its layout.
This list is occasionally not available due to layouts or other events, and callers should be prepared to handle a failure.

member.param: The newly created text view.

summary.para: Represents a helper class for accessing the view's collection of objects. The TextViewLines property on the is used to get an instance of this interface.

remarks.para: The disposes its and all the objects it contains every time it generates a new layout.

Most properties and parameters that are doubles correspond to coordinates or distances in the text rendering coordinate system. In this coordinate system, x = 0.0 corresponds to the left edge of the drawing surface onto which text is rendered (x = view.ViewportLeft corresponds to the left edge of the viewport), and y = view.ViewportTop corresponds to the top edge of the viewport. The x-coordinate increases from left to right, and the y-coordinate increases from top to bottom.

The horizontal and vertical axes of the view behave differently. When the text in the view is formatted, only the visible lines are formatted. As a result, a viewport cannot be scrolled horizontally and vertically in the same way.
A viewport is scrolled horizontally by changing the left coordinate of the viewport so that it moves with respect to the drawing surface.
A view can be scrolled vertically only by performing a new layout.

Doing a layout in the view may cause the ViewportTop property of the view to change. For example, scrolling down one line will not translate any of the visible lines. Instead it will simply change the view's ViewportTop property (causing the lines to move on the screen even though their y-coordinates have not changed).

Distances in the text rendering coordinate system correspond to logical pixels. If the text rendering surface is displayed without any scaling transform, then 1 unit in the text rendering coordinate system corresponds to one pixel on the display.

summary.para: Maps between character positions and fractions of the total vertical extent of an .

remarks.para: Valid text positions range are [0...TextView.TextSnapshot.Length]. Valid scrollbar coordinates are [0.0 ... 1.0]. 0.0 corresponds to the top of the first line in the text view; 1.0 corresponds to the bottom of the last line in the view. Not every text position will have a unique value. For example, every character on the same text buffer line will have the same value, assuming that word wrap is not enabled.
This interface is the base type of the interface, which is created using the .

member.summary: Gets the y-coordinate of the top of the scrollbar track as it is rendered in the display (excluding the scroll buttons at the top and bottom).

remarks.para: If mapping from scrollbar coordinates to positions in the scrollbar's track, the correct mapping is:
pixel position = (scrollbar coordinate * TrackSpanHeight / (Map.Maximum + Map.ViewportSize)) + TrackSpanTop
scrollbar coordinate = (pixel position - TrackSpanTop) * (Map.Maximum + Map.ViewportSize) / TrackSpanHeight

member.name: P:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.Editor.IVerticalScrollBar.TrackSpanBottom
member.summary: Gets the y-coordinate of the bottom of the scrollbar track as it is rendered in the display (excluding the scroll buttons at the top and bottom).

member.name: P:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.Editor.IVerticalScrollBar.TrackSpanHeight
member.summary: Gets the height of the scrollbar track as it is rendered in the display (excluding the scroll buttons at the top and bottom).

member.name: E:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.Editor.IVerticalScrollBar.TrackSpanChanged
member.summary: Occurs when the span of the scrollbar track dimensions is changed. For example, they could change as a result of resizing the view.

member.name: T:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.Editor.IViewScroller
member.summary: Represents a helper class for the , and provides basic functionality for scrolling. The property of is used to get an instance of the this interface.

remarks.para: Most properties and parameters that are doubles correspond to coordinates or distances in the text rendering coordinate system. In this coordinate system, x = 0.0 corresponds to the left edge of the drawing surface onto which text is rendered (x = view.ViewportLeft corresponds to the left edge of the viewport), and y = view.ViewportTop corresponds to the top edge of the viewport. The x-coordinate increases from left to right, and the y-coordinate increases from top to bottom.

The horizontal and vertical axes of the view behave differently. When the text in the view is formatted, only the visible lines are formatted. As a result, a viewport cannot be scrolled horizontally and vertically in the same way.
A viewport is scrolled horizontally by changing the left coordinate of the viewport so that it moves with respect to the drawing surface.
A view can be scrolled vertically only by performing a new layout.

Doing a layout in the view may cause the ViewportTop property of the view to change. For example, scrolling down one line will not translate any of the visible lines. Instead it will simply change the view's ViewportTop property (causing the lines to move on the screen even though their y-coordinates have not changed).

Distances in the text rendering coordinate system correspond to logical pixels. If the text rendering surface is displayed without any scaling transform, then 1 unit in the text rendering coordinate system corresponds to one pixel on the display.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.Editor.IViewScroller.ScrollViewportVerticallyByPixels(System.Double)
member.summary: Scrolls the viewport vertically by .
member.param: The distance to scroll in the text rendering coordinate system. Positive values scroll the viewport up, and negative values scroll the viewport down.

remarks.para: This can be very slow for large numbers of pixels. You should avoid using this method to scroll more than the height of the viewport in either direction.
The viewport always contains at least one visible line along its top edge, and the distance scrolled will be clipped to ensure that this always remains true.

member.exception: is NaN.

member.summary: Scrolls the viewport vertically one line up or down.
member.param: The direction in which to scroll.

remarks.para: The viewport always contains at least one visible line along its top edge, and the distance scrolled is clipped to ensure that this always remains true.

member.exception: is not a .

member.summary: Scrolls the viewport vertically by multiple lines up or down.
member.param: The direction in which to scroll.
The number of lines to scroll up or down.

remarks.para: The viewport always contains at least one visible line along its top edge, and the distance scrolled is clipped to ensure that this always remains true.

is negative.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.Editor.IViewScroller.ScrollViewportVerticallyByPage(Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.Editor.ScrollDirection)
member.summary: Scrolls the viewport vertically one page up or down.
member.param: The direction in which to scroll.
member.returns: true if the view was scrolled by a full page. false if the view had been positioned near the top/bottom of the document and, as a result, scrolled by less than the height of the viewport.

remarks.para: The view will be scrolled by the height of the viewport minus whatever is needed to have the first line of the viewport be flush with the top of the view.
The view cannot be scrolled so that there is a gap between the top of the view and the first line of text.
The view cannot be scrolled the last line of the buffer is above the top of the view.

member.exception: is not a .

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.Editor.IViewScroller.ScrollViewportHorizontallyByPixels(System.Double)
member.summary: Scrolls the viewport horizontally by .
member.param: The distance to scroll the viewport in the text rendering coordinate system. Positive values scroll the viewport to the right, and negative values scroll the viewport to the left.
member.exception: is NaN.
member.remarks: A view cannot be scrolled horizontally if word wrap is enabled. If word wrap is disabled, the horizontal offset of the view must be between [0.0, max(0.0, formatted content width - viewport width)].

member.summary: Ensures that all the text in is entirely visible in the view.
member.param: The span to make visible.
The .
member.remarks: The view will not be scrolled if the text in is completely visible. If the text in is partially visible, then the view will be scrolled as little as possible to make the text completely visible. If none of the text in was visible, then it will be centered in the view.

member.summary: When implemented in a derived class, moves this point to the start of the line in the TextView that it is currently on.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.Editor.DisplayTextPoint.MoveToBeginningOfNextViewLine
member.summary: When implemented in a derived class, moves this point to the beginning of the next line in the TextView.

remarks.para: This point moves to the end of the line if the point is on the last line.
This value could be affected by whether or not Word Wrap is turned on in the view.
If the point is on the last line of the file, the caret is moved to the end of the line.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.Editor.DisplayTextPoint.MoveToBeginningOfPreviousViewLine
member.summary: When implemented in a derived class, moves this point to the beginning of the previous line in the TextView.

remarks.para: This point moves to the start of the line if the point is on the first line.
This value could be affected by whether or not Word Wrap is turned on in the view.
If the point is on the first line of the file, the caret is moved to the beginning of the line.

member.name: T:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.Editor.Tags.ContainerStructureTag
member.summary: Extends with property improving structure visualization support for secondary structure elements such as C# "else" statement, also support for the "catch" and "case"statement.
Constructs an instance of the .
member.remarks: StructureTag offers explicit control of the block structure adornments. This class operates on the pay-to-play principle, in that, it will allow you to create a tag with just a subset of fields, but if a field is missing, it will attempt to guess the missing fields from the information that it has. The most useful example of this is to omit the GuideLineSpan and GuideLineHorizontalAnchorPoint to have the API guess them from the HeaderSpan and StatementSpan indentation. If enough information is missing, the tag does nothing.
member.param: The snapshot used to generate this StructureTag.
The block contents, used to determine the collapse region.
The control statement at the start of the block.
The vertical span within which the block structure guide is drawn. If this member is omitted, it is computed from the HeaderSpan and the OutliningSpan via heuristics.
A point capturing the horizontal offset at which the guide is drawn. If this member is omitted, it is computed from the HeaderSpan and the OutliningSpan via heuristics.
The structure type of the block.
If true, block will have block adornments.
If true, block is collapsed by default.
Defines whether or not the block defines a region following a function declaration.
The form the block appears when collapsed.
The form of the collapsed region tooltip.
Optional subheading control statement of this block (e.g. "catch" statement of the "try" block).

member.name: P:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.Editor.Tags.ContainerStructureTag.SubHeadings
member.summary: Gets the optional of the sub headings of the code block represented by this tag. This Tag will provide below information: Get the whole span of this code block. Gets the span of the statement that controls the structural block. Determines the semantic type of the structural block.

member.name: T:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.BraceCompletion.IBraceCompletionDynamicSessionProvider
member.summary: Represents an extension point used to create an for brace completion. In comparison with , this interface will try to create a session to tracks a brace completion action for every typed characters instead of a defined set of characters defined through the . This interface can be prefered when the kind of braces to handle varies based on the location of the caret in the document. If the braces to handle are fixed (it will always look for the same braces at runtime), then please use instead.

remarks.para: This is a MEF component part, and should be exported with the following attribute: [Export(typeof(IBraceCompletionSessionFreeProvider))]
Exports must include at least one [ContentType] attribute.

member.name: T:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.Classification.IViewClassifierAggregatorService
member.summary: A service that returns an that aggregates and normalizes all contributions for all s in the buffer graph of a particular .

remarks.para: The normalized classifications produced by this aggregator are sorted and do not overlap. If a span of text had multiple classifications based on the original classifier contributions, then in the normalized classification it has a transient classification () that corresponds to all of the original classifications.
Classifier aggregators are cached for each and combination.

member.name: T:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.IncrementalSearch.IIncrementalSearch
member.summary: Defines an incremental search operation.

remarks.para: The interface is associated with a .

After the Start() method is called, the current caret position is marked as the start of the search, and the and operations can be used to change the search term. The direction of the search is set to forward by default, although this setting can be changed with the property. If a matching term is found, it is selected and the caret is moved to the end of the selected word.

Every search operation returns an , which includes information about the search, such as whether the search looped around the start or end of the buffer, whether the search looped around the starting position of the search, and whether the item was found. It is the responsibility of the caller to pass this information to the end user.
Incremental search performs its search on the text snapshot of the . As a result, if the result falls within a collapsed outlining region, the region will be expanded before the result is selected.

member.name: T:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.Formatting.ITextViewLine
member.summary: Represents text that has been formatted for display in a text view.

remarks.para: Most properties and parameters that are doubles correspond to coordinates or distances in the text rendering coordinate system. In this coordinate system, x = 0.0 corresponds to the left edge of the drawing surface onto which text is rendered (x = view.ViewportLeft corresponds to the left edge of the viewport), and y = view.ViewportTop corresponds to the top edge of the viewport. The x-coordinate increases from left to right, and the y-coordinate increases from top to bottom.

The horizontal and vertical axes of the view behave differently. When the text in the view is formatted, only the visible lines are formatted. As a result, a viewport cannot be scrolled horizontally and vertically in the same way.
A viewport is scrolled horizontally by changing the left coordinate of the viewport so that it moves with respect to the drawing surface.
A view can be scrolled vertically only by performing a new layout.

Doing a layout in the view may cause the ViewportTop property of the view to change. For example, scrolling down one line will not translate any of the visible lines. Instead it will simply change the view's ViewportTop property (causing the lines to move on the screen even though their y-coordinates have not changed).

Distances in the text rendering coordinate system correspond to logical pixels. If the text rendering surface is displayed without any scaling transform, then 1 unit in the text rendering coordinate system corresponds to one pixel on the display.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.Formatting.ITextViewLine.GetBufferPositionFromXCoordinate(System.Double,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Gets the buffer position of the character whose character bounds contains the given x-coordinate.
member.param: The x-coordinate of the desired character.
If true, then this method will return null if is over an adornment.
member.returns: The text buffer-based point of the character at x, or null if there is no character at that position.

remarks.para: Please note that the rightmost edge of a character bound is considered to be contained in its following character.
The rightmost edge of the last character's bounds don't map to any character.
If is true and is over an adornment, then the text position assoicated with the adornment is returned.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.Formatting.ITextViewLine.GetBufferPositionFromXCoordinate(System.Double)
member.summary: Gets the buffer position of the character whose character bounds contains the given x-coordinate.
member.param: The x-coordinate of the desired character.
member.returns: The text buffer-based point of the character at x, or null if there is no character at that position.

remarks.para: This is equivalent to GetBufferPositionFromXCoordinate(xCoordinate, false).

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.Formatting.ITextViewLine.GetVirtualBufferPositionFromXCoordinate(System.Double)
member.summary: Gets the buffer position of the character whose character bounds contains the given x-coordinate.
member.param: The x-coordinate of the desired character.
member.returns: The text buffer-based point of the character at x

remarks.para: If there are no characters at the provided x-coordinate, a point in virtual space will be returned.
If the provided x-coordinate is to the left of the start of the line, the buffer position of the line's left edge will be returned.

remarks.para: If there are no characters at the provided x-coordinate, a point in virtual space will be returned.
If the provided x-coordinate is to the left of the start of the line, the buffer position of the line's left edge will be returned.

member.name: T:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.Formatting.LineTransform
member.summary: Represents the transform from a formatted text line to a rendered text line.

remarks.para: Most properties and parameters that are doubles correspond to coordinates or distances in the text rendering coordinate system. In this coordinate system, x = 0.0 corresponds to the left edge of the drawing surface onto which text is rendered (x = view.ViewportLeft corresponds to the left edge of the viewport), and y = view.ViewportTop corresponds to the top edge of the viewport. The x-coordinate increases from left to right, and the y-coordinate increases from top to bottom.

The horizontal and vertical axes of the view behave differently. When the text in the view is formatted, only the visible lines are formatted. As a result, a viewport cannot be scrolled horizontally and vertically in the same way.
A viewport is scrolled horizontally by changing the left coordinate of the viewport so that it moves with respect to the drawing surface.
A view can be scrolled vertically only by performing a new layout.

Doing a layout in the view may cause the ViewportTop property of the view to change. For example, scrolling down one line will not translate any of the visible lines. Instead it will simply change the view's ViewportTop property (causing the lines to move on the screen even though their y-coordinates have not changed).

Distances in the text rendering coordinate system correspond to logical pixels. If the text rendering surface is displayed without any scaling transform, then 1 unit in the text rendering coordinate system corresponds to one pixel on the display.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.Formatting.LineTransform.#ctor(System.Double)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of a .
member.param: The vertical scale factor to be applied to the text of the line, but not the space above and below the line.

remarks.para: All objects on a formatted line of text are combined using the operator below. The resulting determines the placement and scaling of the rendered line of text.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.Formatting.LineTransform.#ctor(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of a .
member.param: The amount of space required above the text of the line before applying .
The amount of space required below the text of the line before applying .
The vertical scale factor to be applied to the text of the line, but not the space above and below the line.

remarks.para: All the objects on a formatted line of text are combined using the operator, and the combined determines the placement and scaling of the rendered line of text.
Negative and values will be ignored, since they will always be combined with at least one with non-negative space requests.
The rendered height of a line will be ((line text height) + + ) * .

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.Formatting.LineTransform.#ctor(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of a .
member.param: The amount of space required above the text of the line before applying .
The amount of space required below the text of the line before applying .
The vertical scale factor to be applied to the text of the line and the space above and below the line.
The x-coordinate of the right edge the line (typically the right edge of any adornment on the line that extends to the right of the line's text).

remarks.para: All the objects on a formatted line of text are combined using the operator, and the combined determines the placement and scaling of the rendered line of text.
Negative and values will be ignored, since they will always be combined with at least one with non-negative space requests.
The rendered height of a line will be ((line text height) + + ) * .

remarks.para: Most properties and parameters that are doubles correspond to coordinates or distances in the text rendering coordinate system. In this coordinate system, x = 0.0 corresponds to the left edge of the drawing surface onto which text is rendered (x = view.ViewportLeft corresponds to the left edge of the viewport), and y = view.ViewportTop corresponds to the top edge of the viewport. The x-coordinate increases from left to right, and the y-coordinate increases from top to bottom.

The horizontal and vertical axes of the view behave differently. When the text in the view is formatted, only the visible lines are formatted. As a result, a viewport cannot be scrolled horizontally and vertically in the same way.
A viewport is scrolled horizontally by changing the left coordinate of the viewport so that it moves with respect to the drawing surface.
A view can be scrolled vertically only by performing a new layout.

Doing a layout in the view may cause the ViewportTop property of the view to change. For example, scrolling down one line will not translate any of the visible lines. Instead it will simply change the view's ViewportTop property (causing the lines to move on the screen even though their y-coordinates have not changed).

Distances in the text rendering coordinate system correspond to logical pixels. If the text rendering surface is displayed without any scaling transform, then 1 unit in the text rendering coordinate system corresponds to one pixel on the display.

member.name: P:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.IMultiSelectionBroker.IsBoxSelection

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.IMultiSelectionBroker.BreakBoxSelection
member.summary: Clears , but retains the current state of selections. This is a useful utility when performing gestures like End and Home where each selection moves, but the result is not necessarily a box.

member.name: P:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.IMultiSelectionBroker.SelectedSpans
member.summary: Gets the list of spans within that are selected. While two selections cannot overlap, they may inhabit virtual space, and selections may be adjacent. This will merge those spans and return the minimum set of spans that could be used to describe the selection. This can be a costly operation and should only be run when needed.

member.name: P:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.IMultiSelectionBroker.VirtualSelectedSpans
member.summary: Gives the set of spans selected. There is exactly one span per selection, but it may be empty. They will be sorted in the order of appearence in the document.

member.name: P:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.IMultiSelectionBroker.SelectionExtent
member.summary: Gets the span containing all selections, complete with virtual space.

member.name: P:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.IMultiSelectionBroker.AreSelectionsActive
member.summary: Whether or not selections are active within .

remarks.para: If is true, this property is automatically updated when the gains and loses aggregate focus. You can still override it while is false, but the value will change whenever focus changes.

member.name: P:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.IMultiSelectionBroker.ActivationTracksFocus
member.summary: Determines whether should track when the gains and loses aggregate focus. The default is true.

remarks.para: While the value of this property is true, the value of will track . When the value of this property changes to true, the value of will be immediately updated.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.ISelectionTransformer.CapturePreferredReferencePoint
member.summary: Updates internal state to cache the current location as the desired reference point for navigation events.
member.remarks: This affects events like where the current X location of the rendered caret is used to project to the new location. Typically this method should be called in cases where the user is stating where they want to focus. Since this grabs the current state, there is no equivalent release method.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.ISelectionTransformer.CapturePreferredXReferencePoint
member.summary: Updates internal state to cache the current x location as the desired reference point for navigation events.
member.remarks: This affects events like where the current X location of the rendered caret is used to project to the new location. Typically this method should be called in cases where the user is stating where they want to focus. Since this grabs the current state, there is no equivalent release method.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.ISelectionTransformer.CapturePreferredYReferencePoint
member.summary: Updates internal state to cache the current y location as the desired reference point for navigation events.
member.remarks: This affects events like where the current Y location of the rendered caret is used to project to the new location. Typically this method should be called in cases where the user is stating where they want to focus. Since this grabs the current state, there is no equivalent release method.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.Operations.IEditorOperations.DeleteBlankLines
member.summary: Deletes all empty lines or lines that contain only white space in the selection.
member.returns: true if the edit succeeded, otherwise false.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.Operations.IEditorOperations.DeleteHorizontalWhiteSpace
member.summary: Deletes all white space from the beginnings and ends of the selected lines, and trims internal white space.
member.returns: true if the edit succeeded, otherwise false.

remarks.para: The algorithm for this operation follows these rules:
If there is no selection, the white space around the caret is trimmed so that only one space or tab remains. If there is only one space or tab, then this operation does nothing.

If there is a selection, then the white space at the beginning or end of a line contained within the selection is completely deleted. If there is at least one block of contiguous white space longer than one character in the selection, then all white space between the first and last non-white space characters is trimmed so that only one space or tab remains for each contiguous block. If there are only contiguous runs of a single space or tab contained within the selection, then all spaces and tabs in the selection are deleted.

member.summary: Inserts the given text at the current caret position as a box.

member.name: T:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.IOvertypeManager
member.summary: A per text view manager for overtype.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.IOvertypeManager.TryStartOvertypeSession(Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.SnapshotSpan)
member.summary: Starts a new overtype session for the given snapshot span.
member.param: The range on which overtype should be possible.
member.returns: Returns True if the session has been created.

remarks.para: A session will be created only if the caret position is within the given range.

If all the characters in the to the left and right of the caret are identical at the moment when the session is created (for example, "|"), then all the characters on the left and right can be overtyped.
If characters to the left and right of the are different, then only characters to the right of the caret can be overtyped. For example, creating a session on `` will only allow to overtype `-->`.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.IOvertypeManager.TryStartOvertypeSession(Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.SnapshotSpan,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Starts a new overtype session for the given snapshot span.
member.param: The range on which overtype should be possible.
(optional) Indicates whether the span before the caret can be overtyped.
member.returns: Returns True if the session has been created.

remarks.para: A session will be created only if the caret position is within the given range.

If all the characters in the to the left and right of the caret are identical at the moment when the session is created (for example, "|") and that is true, then all the characters on the left and right can be overtyped.
If characters to the left and right of the are different, then only characters to the right of the caret can be overtyped. For example, creating a session on `` will only allow to overtype `-->`.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.IOvertypeManager.TryStartOvertypeSessionAtCaretLocation
member.summary: Starts a new overtype session at the caret location.
member.returns: Returns True if the session has been created.

remarks.para: A session will be created only if the characters around the caret correspond to a brace pair supported by in the current content type or document.
If all the characters of the opening and closing brace pair are identical (for example, "|"), then all the characters on the left and right of the caret can be overtyped.

If the brace pair has different opening and closing brace characters, then only characters to the right of the caret can be overtyped. For example, creating a session on `` will only allow to overtype `-->`.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.IOvertypeManager.TryStartOvertypeSessionAtCaretLocation(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Starts a new overtype session at the caret location.
member.param: (optional) Indicates whether the span before the caret can be overtyped.
member.returns: Returns True if the session has been created.

remarks.para: A session will be created only if the characters around the caret correspond to a brace pair supported by in the current content type or document.
If all the characters of the opening and closing brace pair are identical (for example, "|") and that is true, then all the characters on the left and right of the caret can be overtyped.

If the brace pair has different opening and closing brace characters, then only characters to the right of the caret can be overtyped. For example, creating a session on `` will only allow to overtype `-->`.

member.name: T:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.SpellChecker.ISpellCheckFixerProvider
member.summary: Exportable interface implemented to support rename functionality for spelling errors.
member.remarks:
Content-type specific providers implement this interface to respond to rename spell checking error code actions.
This is a MEF component part, and should be exported with the following attributes: [Export(typeof(ISpellCheckFixerProvider))] [ContentType("code")] [Name("SpellCheckFixerProvider")]
Component exporters must add at least one ContentType attribute to specify the content types the provider is valid for.

member.name: T:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.Tagging.IViewTaggerProvider
member.summary: Creates an for a given buffer.
member.remarks:
This is a MEF component part, and implementers must use the following attributes: [Export(typeof(ITaggerProvider))] Exports must specify at least one content type attribute and at least one tag type attribute. Exports may optionally specify a TextViewRole; if no TextViewRole is specified, the tagger applies to views with any roles.
[Export(typeof(ITaggerProvider))] [ContentType(...)] // Required, must have at least one (and can have multiple ContentType attributes) // Specifies the s which this provider provides taggers. [TextViewRole(...))] // Optional, can have multiple s. // Specifies the required roles that a view must have before this tagger is created. [TagType(...))] // Required, must have at least one (and can have multiple TagType attributes) // Specifies the types of taggers that can be created by this provider. [Name(...)] // Required, can have only one // Specifies the name of the tagger provider. // Providers with a name attribute can be replaced by another tagger provider that specifies // the name in their . // In addition, providers with the same name as an will automatically // suppress that provider if this provider's returns a tagger. [Replaces(...)] // Optional, can have zero or more // Providers with a name attribute that matches replaces attribute of another provider will // be suppressed. Note that the other tagger is suppressed even if the replacing provider does not // supply a tagger. [DeferCreation(OptionName = ...)] // Optional, can have only one // If specified, the tagger will not be created until the option () specified // in the defer creation attribute becomes true.

member.name: T:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.Tagging.IStructureTag
member.summary: Represents a structural code block, which is used for vertical structural line adornments and outlining collapse regions.

member.name: P:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.Tagging.IStructureTag.Snapshot
member.summary: The Snapshot from which this IStructureTag was generated.

member.name: P:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.Tagging.IStructureTag.OutliningSpan
member.summary: Gets the span containing the entire contents of the block (minus the block header). This span will be collapsed or expanded when the block outlining adornment is invoked.
member.remarks: If this parameter is null, block structure adornments will still be drawn as long as the and the are both provided, however, no outlining adornment will be drawn.

member.name: P:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.Tagging.IStructureTag.HeaderSpan
member.summary: Gets the span of the statement that controls the structural block.

remarks.para: If this parameter is null, block structure adornments will still be drawn as long as the is provided, or the and the are both provided.

member.name: P:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.Tagging.IStructureTag.GuideLineSpan
member.summary: Gets the vertical span within which the block structure adornment will be drawn.
member.remarks: For a block to have an adornment, it must not be of type , and the implementer must also provide the GuideLineHorizontalAnchor. The adornment is drawn from the top of the line containing the start of the span to the bottom of the line containing the bottom of the span. If null, the GuideLineSpan is inferred from the OutliningSpan and the HeaderSpan.

member.name: P:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.Tagging.IStructureTag.GuideLineHorizontalAnchorPoint
member.summary: Gets the point with which the block structure adornment will be horizontally aligned.
member.remarks: This point can be on any line and is used solely for determining horizontal position. If null, or if is null, this point is computed from the HeaderSpan and OutliningSpan via heuristics.

member.name: P:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.Tagging.IStructureTag.Type
member.summary: Determines the semantic type of the structural block.
member.remarks: See for the canonical types. Use for blocks that will not have any visible affordance (but will be used for outlining).

member.summary: Determines whether a block is collapsed by default.

member.summary: Determines whether a block is an implementation block.
member.remarks: Implementation blocks are the blocks of code following a method definition. They are used for commands such as the Visual Studio Collapse to Definition command, which hides the implementation block and leaves only the method definition exposed.

member.name: T:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Text.Tagging.StructureTag
member.summary: An implementation of .
member.remarks: Using this class is the recommended way to create an instance of for most purposes.

member.summary: Constructs an instance of the .
member.remarks: StructureTag offers explicit control of the block structure adornments. This class operates on the pay-to-play principle, in that, it will allow you to create a tag with just a subset of fields, but if a field is missing, it will attempt to guess the missing fields from the information that it has. The most useful example of this is to omit the GuideLineSpan and GuideLineHorizontalAnchorPoint to have the API guess them from the HeaderSpan and StatementSpan indentation. If enough information is missing, the tag does nothing.
member.param: The snapshot used to generate this StructureTag.
The block contents, used to determine the collapse region.
The control statement at the start of the block.
The vertical span within which the block structure guide is drawn. If this member is omitted, it is computed from the HeaderSpan and the OutliningSpan via heuristics.
A point capturing the horizontal offset at which the guide is drawn. If this member is omitted, it is computed from the HeaderSpan and the OutliningSpan via heuristics.
The structure type of the block.
If true, block will have block adornments.
If true, block is collapsed by default.
Defines whether or not the block defines a region following a function declaration.
The form the block appears when collapsed.
The form of the collapsed region tooltip.

member.summary: Constructs an instance of the .
member.remarks: StructureTag offers explicit control of the block structure adornments. This class operates on the pay-to-play principle, in that, it will allow you to create a tag with just a subset of fields, but if a field is missing, it will attempt to guess the missing fields from the information that it has. The most useful example of this is to omit the GuideLineSpan and GuideLineHorizontalAnchorPoint to have the API guess them from the HeaderSpan and StatementSpan indentation. If enough information is missing, the tag does nothing.
member.param: The snapshot used to generate this StructureTag.
The block contents, used to determine the collapse region.
The control statement at the start of the block.
The vertical span within which the block structure guide is drawn. If this member is omitted, it is computed from the HeaderSpan and the OutliningSpan via heuristics.
A point capturing the horizontal offset at which the guide is drawn. If this member is omitted, it is computed from the HeaderSpan and the OutliningSpan via heuristics.
The structure type of the block.
If true, block will have block adornments.
If true, block is collapsed by default.
Defines whether or not the block defines a region following a function declaration.
The form the block appears when collapsed.
The form of the collapsed region tooltip.
Optional primary control statement of this block (e.g. "if" statement of the "else" block).

member.name: T:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Utilities.IUIThreadOperationContext
member.summary: Represents a context of executing potentially long running operation on the UI thread, which enables shared two way cancellability and wait indication.
member.remarks: Instances implementing this interface are produced by MEF component.

member.name: P:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Utilities.IUIThreadOperationContext.UserCancellationToken
member.summary: Cancellation token that allows user to cancel the operation unless the operation is not cancellable.

member.name: P:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Utilities.IUIThreadOperationContext.AllowCancellation
member.summary: Gets whether the operation can be cancelled.
member.remarks: This value is composed of initial AllowCancellation value and values of all currently added scopes. The value composition logic takes into acount disposed scopes too - if any of added scopes were disposed while its was false, this property will stay false regardless of all other scopes' values.

member.name: P:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Utilities.IUIThreadOperationContext.Description
member.summary: Gets user readable operation description, composed of initial context description and descriptions of all currently added scopes.

member.name: P:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Utilities.IUIThreadOperationContext.Scopes
member.summary: Gets current list of s in this context.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Utilities.IUIThreadOperationContext.AddScope(System.Boolean,System.String)
member.summary: Adds a UI thread operation scope with its own two way cancellability, description and progress tracker. The scope is removed from the context on dispose.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Utilities.IUIThreadOperationContext.TakeOwnership
member.summary: Allows a component to take full ownership over this UI thread operation, for example when it shows its own modal UI dialog and handles cancellability through that dialog instead.

member.name: T:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Utilities.IUIThreadOperationExecutor
member.summary: Executes potentially long running operation on the UI thread and provides shared two way cancellability and wait indication.

remarks.para: Visual Studio implementation of this service measures operation execution duration and displays a modal wait dialog if it takes too long. The wait dialog describes operation to the user, optionally provides progress information and allows user to cancel the operation if it can be cancelled. Components running in the operation can affect the wait dialog via provided by this service.

Host specific implementations of this service should be exported as follows:
[ExportImplementation(typeof(IUIThreadOperationExecutor))] [Name("Visual Studio UI thread operation executor")] [Order(Before = "default")] internal sealed class VSUIThreadOperationExecutor : IUIThreadOperationExecutor
All methods of this interface should only be called on the UI thread.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Utilities.IUIThreadOperationExecutor.Execute(System.String,System.String,System.Boolean,System.Boolean,System.Action{Microsoft.VisualStudio.Utilities.IUIThreadOperationContext})
member.summary: Executes the action synchronously and waits for it to complete.
member.param: Operation's title. Can be null to indicate that the wait dialog should use the application's title.
Default operation's description, which is displayed on the wait dialog unless one or more s with more specific descriptions were added to the .
Whether to allow cancellability.
Whether to show progress indication.
An action to execute.
member.returns: A status of action execution.

member.summary: Executes the action synchronously and waits for it to complete.
member.param: Options that control action execution behavior.
An action to execute.
member.returns: A status of action execution.

member.summary: Begins executing potentially long running operation on the caller thread and provides a context object that provides access to shared cancellability and wait indication.
member.param: Operation's title. Can be null to indicate that the wait dialog should use the application's title.
Default operation's description, which is displayed on the wait dialog unless one or more s with more specific descriptions were added to the .
Whether to allow cancellability.
Whether to show progress indication.
member.returns: instance that provides access to shared two way cancellability and wait indication for the given operation. The operation is considered executed when this instance is disposed.

member.summary: A controller that enables and controls auto-cancellation of an operation execution by on a timeout.

member.name: P:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Utilities.IUIThreadOperationTimeoutController.CancelAfter
member.summary: The duration (in milliseconds) after which an operation shouold be auto-cancelled.
member.remarks: disables auto-cancellation.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Utilities.IUIThreadOperationTimeoutController.ShouldCancel
member.summary: Gets whether an operation, whose execution time exceeded timeout should be cancelled.
member.remarks: This callback can be used to disable auto-cancellation when an operation already passed the point of no cancellation and it would leave system in an inconsistent state. This method is called on a background thread.

members.member:
An event callback raised when an operation execution timeout was reached.
Indicates whether an operation was auto-cancelled. Might be false if the operation is not cancellable ( is false or returned false. 7 This method is called on a background thread.

member.summary: An event callback raised when a UI thread operation execution took long enough to be considered as a delay. Visual Studio implementation of the displays a wait dialog at this point.
member.remarks: This method is called on a background thread.
